    Curing sick system with data

    Nagendra Chatterjee     11 minute read    Read in Hindi   HOME    June 19, 2021   

    Government works on agenda of diverting attention from the picture rather than changing it. Hence, presentable data needs manipulation. Sick person does not need facial but proper medical treatment. Hiding facts is escaping from failure.

    Translated from बीमार व्यवस्था का आँकड़ों से इलाज

    Recently published two reports on ‘Achievements of United Nation’s Sustainable Development Goals – SDGs’ are important for us. One is the national report from ‘NITI AYOG’ and another is from Cambridge University press published ‘International Report on Achievements of Sustainable Development Goals’. Description of achievements in Sustainable Development goals appear in both the reports. We would like to compare the descriptions and analysis of the national report with that of the International.

    With the end of millennium development goals in 2015, the 70th meet of General Body of UN held between 25th September 2015 and 27th September 2015, 17 Development Goals were set, to be achieved by 2030. It was named as Sustainable Development Goals – SDGs. On the very day, the closed fists of 193 nations adopted the resolution of ‘Transforming Our World: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.’ The adopted resolutions were - 1) No Poverty, 2) Zero Hunger, 3) Good Health and Well-being, 4) Quality education, 5) Gender equality, 6) Clean Water and Sanitation, 7) Affordable and Clean Energy, 8) Decent Work and Economic Growth, 9) Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure, 10) Reduced Inequalities, 11) Sustainable Cities and Communities, 12) Responsible Consumption and Production, 13) Climate Action, 14) Life below Water, 15) Life on land, 16) Peace, justice and strong institutions and 17) Partnerships for the Goals.

    Let us begin with the report of ‘NITI AYOG’. In the report, ‘NITI AYOG’ has categorised the states on the basis of achievements. Among 28 states, Kerala stands at first position with 80 points, Bihar is occupying bottom most position with the label of backward state merely having 29 points. Himachal Pradesh came a step below from its first position in last year, where Kerala stepped up from its second position in last year. But last year Bihar was standing at the last position with 19 points and this year too it is maintaining the last position with 29 points. The points may show improvement but with all logic it is established that Bihar is in worse, backward and sick status. The consistent plight of Bihar exposes the falsehood of the slogans, “SAMAJIK NYAY” (Social justice) and “SABKA SATH, SABKA VIKAS” (partnering all, developing all) just influencing the poor and the backwards and used it for unsplit rule for the last three decades.

    10 states among these 28 states – Andhra Pradesh, Meghalaya, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Odisha, Asam, Tripura, Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Bihar are such which got 50 or less points. In these backward states majority is from Hindi speaking and eastern regions of India. Why there is no any improvement in the ailing condition of these states? It needs to find out the reasons. This is to note that popularising the slogan of Gujrat model, blind drive of privatisation is adopted all over the country, it made Uttar Pradesh to improve only by 1 point, from 51 to 52, standing at 17th position is showing its bad luck.

    There is one more interesting point – leaving the union administered states, 10 states enjoy the status of special states. Among the 10 special status states 5 states – Meghalaya, Asam, Tripura, Arunachal Pradesh and Nagaland are in the category of backward states. Asam and Nagaland are enjoying the special status states since 1969. The special status means that 90 percent expenses of these states are to be done by centre. Almost all the expenses born by centre for 50 years, even then these states are among sick states then, it is required to investigate the political, economic, educational conditions rather than providing nutrition to the illness by the tonic of special grants.

    After the state wise performance, let us view the goal wise performance. ‘NITI AYOG’ has released achievements in 15 goals out of 17 goals and granted score points in the years 2020 and 2019. In this report leaving ‘Zero Hunger’ and ‘Gender Equality’ all goals are full of achievements and given 50 points and more. The list is like -

    Goal Year 2020 Year 2019
    No Poverty 60 50
    Zero Hunger 47 35
    Good Health and Well-being 74 61
    Quality Education 57 58
    Gender Equality 48 42
    Clean Water and Sanitation 83 88
    Affordable and Clean Energy 92 70
    Decent Work and Economic Growth 61 64
    Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure 55 65
    Reduced Inequality 67 64
    Sustainable Cities and Communities 79 53
    Responsible Consumption and Production 74 55
    Climate Action 54 60
    Life Below Water —- —-
    Life On Land 66 66
    Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions 74 72
    Partnership for the Goals —- —-

    Leave the national report for a while and let us look at position of India in the International report, is there any acceptance that is revealed in national report?

    The report of United Nations published from Cambridge University Press presents the evaluation of 166 nations. India stands at 117th position with 61.9 points. For South East Asia, where most of the nations are poor, their regional score is 67.2, that is more than India’s. Among listed 166 nations, the 83rd position from bottom means the condition is poor enough to think. 117th position of India means that civic life and protection of rights are not being taken seriously in India and citizens are living in very poor condition. But in the report presented by ‘NITI AYOG’, the seriously struggling condition described in the international report are looking as ‘all is well’.

    The United Nations report has divided the 17 challenges in four groups – 1) SDGs achieved, 2) Challenges Remain, 3) Significant Challenges and 4) Major Challenges. We may say these as excellent, satisfactory, unsatisfactory and serious challenges categories. Achievements points 1 to 25 are poor,26 to 50 are unsatisfactory, 51 to 75 are satisfactory and 76 to 100 are in excellent group.

    United Nations report has put only one challenge in the excellent group means in 76 to 100 point’s group – the ‘Climate Action’. But in the report of ‘NITI AYOG’, the ‘Climate Action’ has come down at 54 points, 6 points less from last year’s 60 points. It is self-acceptance of ‘NITI AYOG’. Means at International level the thing that stands better is challenging inside country. In the international report, three challenges in India are in unsatisfactory group, these are – ‘No Poverty’, ‘Life Below Water’ and ‘Life on Land’. Means these three groups fall in 26 to 50 points and needs attention. ‘NITI AYOG’ has not taken any note on ‘Life Below Water’, ‘No Poverty’ is shown with 60 points and ‘Life on Land’ with 66 points.

    शिक्षा नीति 2020 और सामाजिक विभेद

    नीति राजसत्ता की वह परिकल्पना होती है, जो यह दिखाती है कि व्यवस्था को किन रास्तों से होकर कहाँ तक ले जाना है। इसकी भूमिका दिशा-निर्देशक की होती है। राज्य नीत...

    According to the report of United Nations out of 17 goals, achievement of India in the 10 goals is very poor and cause of concern, these are – ‘No Poverty’, ‘Good Health and Well-being’, ‘Gender Equality’, ‘Clean Water and Sanitation’, ‘Affordable and Clean Energy’, ‘Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure’, ‘Reduced Inequality’, ‘Sustainable Cities and Communities’, ‘Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions’. The ‘NITI AYOG’ report keep most of these in second or third group.

    United Nations Organisation is stating the poor conditions for most of the challenges but the ‘NITI AYOG’ report does not find these challenging rather shows as satisfactory and excellent. Comparing the reports with other studies and also practically the truth of the report of ‘NITI AYOG’ is exposed. Where it is patting its back by giving 74 points to ‘Good Health and Well-being’, but National Family Health Survey (NFHS), 2019-20 says that out of 22 states in 18 states and Union territories among children below 5 years the cases of anaemia are increasing. National Nutrition Survey 2016-18 states that among the children below 5 years, 35 percent children suffer from height deficiency, 33 percent suffer from weight deficiency and 17 percent suffer from weakness. According to this report weight deficient children are maximum in state like Bihar -22.9 percent, means they are suffering from malnutrition. According to global hunger index of 2020 India stands with serious condition at 94th position among 107 nations with score of 27.2 points. According to the report of Hunger Watch, during Corona-lockdown in 2020, 27 percent people slept without food for many nights and 71 percent lost nutritive foods, but the ‘NITI AYOG’ is patting its back for the betterments in the same year. Self-appraised report of ‘NITI AYOG’ is correct or the other reports are correct?

    ‘Good Health and Well-being’ is also related to employment and income. For the same year 2020 when ‘NITI AYOG’ is presenting the report, CMIE stated that the unemployment in month of May in that year went up at 23.5 percent. Right now, on 31st May 2021 the unemployment was 12.15 percent. The consequence of persistent unemployment of 45 years rising up at 24 percent is given by American Institution Pew Research Report, according to the report the rate of poverty is 9.7 percent, in 2020 there is reduction of 3.3 crores in the population of 9.9 crore people of the middle class in India, the population of poor people has gone to 13.4 crores and 7.2 crores have gone below the poverty line. The reality ‘No Poverty’, ‘Zero Hunger’, ‘Good Health and Well-being’, ‘Decent Work and Economic Growth’ the cheerfulness of ‘NITI AYOG’.

    Similarly, ‘Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions’ goal is given 70 points out of 100 by ‘NITI AYOG’. It means that there is no any disturbance in Indian Society, Justiciable system is functioning well, Legislative, Judiciary and Executive along with all other constitutional and legal institutions are working to fulfil the democratic interest. It is also shown in the report of ‘NITI AYOG’ that in 2020 the ‘Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions’ is better than it was in 2019. In a country where series of mob lynching is done on the basis of eaten food or name of a person, the legislature is amending citizenship law targeting citizens from a particular community, detention homes are prepared for dishonouring own citizens who lived here for many generations, on one or other issues the case of treason is filed, the investing agencies run after someone who criticized the government, case is filed against journalist reporting about no proper distribution of mid-day meals in schools, the law enacted for losing opportunity of getting job on participating in strikes and demonstrations, not only media but social media is restrained, how much Peace and Justice is there and how much score points should be given can be well understood by oneself. In the context of civil liberties among 180 nations India slipped from 133 position to 142 in the World Freedom Index of 2020. ‘Democracy under seize’ titled report of ‘Freedom House’ among 211 nations India is ranking 87 from 88 and its score came down to 63 from 71. In ‘Human Freedom Index 2020’ among 162 nations, India’s rank came to 111 from 94 coming down by 17 positions. The international magazine Economist’s annual ‘Democracy Index’ India came down from last year’s 51 position to 53 in 2020. But the report of ‘NITI AYOG’ rejecting all these reports the goal of ‘Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions’ giving 74 score point in 2020 from 72 in last year, tried to revalidate the achievement.

    Similarly, we are trailing behind on the important social criteria of ‘Gender Equality’. In ‘Global Gender Gap’ report among list of 153 nations India was at 112th position in 2019, in 2020 in the list of 156 nations came down to 140th position. According to the report, discrimination on the basis of Gender has gone up by 3 percent coming to 32.6 percent. Female workers participation has gone down to 22.3 percent from 24.8 percent. The report also states that with the things at the same pace, it may take 135.6 years to get gender equality, last year it projected for 99.5 years. Means just in one year we went back to 36 years. The same is true for disparity, which in place of reduction is increasing rapidly. Oxfam report on disparity states that one percent Indians possess 70 percent of property. In the ‘Inequality virus’ report it is said that during the Corona-lockdown period there has been increase of 35 percent in properties of 100 riches, when 12 crores of people have lost their jobs. The score points of ‘Affordable and Clean Energy’ raised to 92 points from 70 points, the example of rising prices of diesel, petrol, cooking gas tells the fact itself. Clean energy situation is such that in Delhi odd-even numbered vehicles are plied.

    ‘NITI AYOG’ has given high score points to the goals which are seriously in quavering condition. Looking at the report it seems that the score points are given on desire without considering any fact. What can be the reason of hiding the facts and what will be its result? The reason lies in the policy of government. Government works on agenda of diverting attention from the picture rather than changing it. Hence, presentable data needs manipulation. Sick person does not need facial but proper medical treatment. Hiding facts is escaping from failure. The fact hiding also indicates that in reality we are uninterested in achieving goals. This is breach of trust with people.
